author: sky.cactus
content: I believe zkSync contracts are upgradable, so they can steal everything.

author: liberosist
content: I do like that zkSync's contracts are time-locked, so even if the multi-sig (reputable people from the Ethereum ecosystem) are compromised, you still have an exit window. I believe this is an acceptable solution at this early stage, and wish Optimism, Arbitrum and others would do the same.

author: sky.cactus
content: Do you or anyone you know audit zkSync contracts on a regular basis to make sure no one is upgrading, and that no upgrades are malicious?

author: axic3354
content: It is strange that zksync does not even emit an event in case of the implementation upgrade, so one must periodically query `getTarget`.

author: axic3354
content: At least tokens like USDC have an event: https://dune.xyz/queries/97930/196681

author: axic3354
content: (The implementation may emit an event, but the main proxy isn't.)

author: liberosist
content:
No, I don't, I just use zkSync for quick payments. IIRC, there are 15 reputable people (all of whom are doxxed) on zkSync's multi-sig, and you need at least 8 of them to sign for the longest timelock. 

Obviously, this is a very imperfect solution, but I personally prefer it to having a completely centralized upgradability. Of course, I'd like to see immutable contracts, and they'll get there, but this is an understandable intermediate step.

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree it is better than no timelock.  I just argue that it doesn't offer that much over a multisig without a timelock if there aren't easy-to-use and censorship resistant tools for monitoring the timelock by end users.

author: codeknight
content: Most likely attack vectors involves compromising the multi-sig accounts. A time lock does give the people with the keys some time to notice the attack.
